issue.title: Add Interpretation class and refactor some existing interpretations
issue.body:
pair coded with @fritzo 

This refactors interpretations to be first-class objects, instances of subclasses of a base `Interpretation` class. Interpretations can be used directly as context managers and decorators. Most interpretation classes and objects have been moved to the new file `funsor.interpretations`; of the remaining interpretations, @fritzo would like to move the remaining `Memoize` and `MonteCarlo` into this file in a future PR, but others may stay where they are (`Substitute`, `AdjointTape`, `Optimize`).

## Proposed interface changes

| Old | New |
| ---: | :--- |
| `with interpretation(eager): ...` | `with eager: ...` |
| `@interpretation(eager)` | `@eager` |
| `eager(cls, *args)` | `eager.interpret(cls, *args)` |
| `@dispatched_interpretation` | `@DispatchedInterpretation` |
| `from funsor.terms import eager` | `from funsor.interpretations import eager` |

## Tests to fix

- [x] test/examples/test_bart.py::test_bart[monte-carlo-kl]
- [x] test/pyroapi/test_pyroapi.py::test_nested_plate_plate_ok[jit]
- [x] test/test_minipyro.py::test_nested_plate_plate_ok[funsor-py]
- [x] test/test_minipyro.py::test_nested_plate_plate_ok[funsor-jit]

issue.title: Add an Approximate funsor for use in adjoint algorithms
issue.body:
Addresses #446 
pair coded with @eb8680 

This was initially called `Importance(arg, proposal, vars)` in the [design doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jbpGwAJLAfTAi6IZyPUSArgXt_Km49573UI7izsDvsE/edit#).

## Tested
- [x] eager tests
- [x] MonteCarlo tests
- [x] moment_matching tests

body:
Just throwing out an idea here. Another perspective on two different semi-rings (ops.add, ops.mul) and (ops.logaddexp, ops.add) is to view the latter as operations lifted by a `Log` Functor. In Haskell notation:

```hs
instance Functor Log where
    fmap f :: Log a -> Log b
    fmap f (Log a) = Log (f a)

...

fmap (*) (Log (x, y)) = Log (x*y) = Log x + Log y
fmap (+)  = logaddexp
```

These two different types could be represented by something like `Factor` and `Logfactor` funsors which can be used for pattern matching. Not sure if this adds anything new though.

As a side note, can Funsor be used to represent partially applied functions?

@ordabayevy yes I think your `Log` functor relates the semiring pair `((add,mul), (logaddexp,add))` and the pair `((max,mul),(max,add))`. However no functor relates e.g. the pair `((add,mul), (max,add))`.

Indeed `Funsor`s can represent functions, and funsor substitution represents partially applied functions.

issue.title: Implement Scatter funsor
issue.body:
Addresses #446 
Blocking #445
pair coded with @eb8680 

This implements a scatter-reduce funsor `Scatter` that fuses a transpose-`Subs` operation with a `Reduce` operation. This new `Scatter` is roughly a funsor analog of `torch.scatter_add`, but generalized to arbitrary associative ops and to more flexible (and named) indexing.

## Tested
- [x] unit tests of `Scatter(ops.add, ..., Tensor(...), ...)`

issue.title: Autodiff implementation (experimental)
issue.body:
This is an implementation of autodiff. The goal is to address issues in computing expectations in `TraceEnum_ELBO` and `TraceMarkovEnum_ELBO` (#493). As of now it seems to fix `nan` gradients under `eager` interpretation in `TraceEnum_ELBO`.

The algorithm implements equivalents of `linearize()`, `transpose()` functions, and is tape-free (#446). 

1. **Linearize.** Variables that need to be linearized are replaced by primal- tangent tuple `JVP(primal, tangent)` and then pattern matched to propagate tangents, e.g.:

```py
JVP(x, dx) + JVP(y, dy) = JVP(x+y, dx+dy)
JVP(x, dx) * JVP(y, dy) = JVP(x*y, ydx + xdy)
JVP(x, dx) * y = JVP(x*y, ydx)
```

Out tangent is a linear function of in tangents. `JVP` is used for `(add,mul)` semiring and `LJVP` is used for `(logaddexp,add)` semiring.

2. **Transpose of a linear function.** Transpose is implemented simply by inverting the order of function execution and transposing matrices, in this case swapping more primitive operations `.reduce(sum_op, "i")` and `.expand("i")` (broadcasting does this automatically).
